predicate.note: Frames file for 'bring' based on survey of initial sentences of big corpus

roleset.name: carry along with

example.name: active, attributive
example.text: The surge brings to nearly 50 the number of country funds that are listed in New York or London.
example.arg: the number of country funds that are listed in New York or London.

roleset.note: This is arg3 not arg2 because now the "number of country funds" IS "nearly 50", not HAS "nearly 50".

example.name: with ablative
example.text: They may risk *trace* bringing some damaging influence from outside the markets.

example.name: active, attributive again
example.text: Bush administration officials are looking to the Fed *trace* to bring down rates.

roleset.note: Follow PReditor's suggestions for phrasal brings--the particle is often the same as an attribute, but they can cooccur (eg "bring in as president").

example.name: passive, attributive
example.text: ...the Whiting field, the first of five small fields scheduled *trace1* to be brought *trace2* into production before the end of 1990.

roleset.name: raise
roleset.note: I don't know that all of these will be needed, but here they are just in case.

example.name: issues
example.text: The meeting brought up important issues that everyone ignored.

example.name: children
example.text: *trace* Bringing up children is hard on a graduate student's wages.

roleset.name: make fall
roleset.note: I don't know that all of these will be needed, but here they are just in case.

example.name: the government
example.text: The vote could have brought down Pakistan's government.

predicate.note: PReditor doesn't accept this as a phrasal, but it's more so than "bring in" or any of the others PReditor does accept. But whatever.

roleset.note: Use the roles found in the "carry along with" roleset

example.name: bring along
example.text: She could bring along her humility and a little thespian skill.
example.arg: her humility and a little thespian skill
